case_name: Proprietor of Sri Vinayagar Transports v. Southern Roadways Private Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 262 of 1958 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 262 of 1958. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal arose from Madras High Court judgment and order dated July 17, 1957 in Writ Appeal No. 110 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 17, 1957, of the Madras High Court, in Writ Appeal No. 110 of 1956,

facts.text: Writ Appeal No. 110 of 1956 arose from judgment and order dated September 3, 1956 of Madras High Court in Writ Petition No. 2/1956.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated September 3, 1956, of the said High Court in Writ Petition No. 2/1956.

facts.text: Appellant is the proprietor of Sri Vinayagar Transports, Woriyur, Tiruchirapalli.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the proprietor of Sri Vinayagar Transports, Woriyur, Tiruchirapalli. He held a permit to ply his bus

facts.text: Appellant held a permit to ply his bus on the route Tiruchirapalli Mainguard Gate to Tiruchirapalli Railway Station via Palakarai and Round Tana.

anchor.surface_text: He held a permit to ply his bus on the route Tiruchirapalli Mainguard Gate to Tiruchirapalli Railway Station via Palakarai and Round Tana.

facts.text: Appellant applied on July 19, 1954 to Regional Transport Officer, Tiruchirapalli for variation of route to ply between Mainguard Gate and Golden Rock via Palakarai, Round Tana, Tiruchirapalli Railway Station and retrace to Golden Rock.

anchor.surface_text: He applied on July 19, 1954, to the Regional Transport Officer, Tiruchirapalli, for variation of the route so as to ply his bus between Mainguard Gate and Golden Rock via Palakarai, Round Tana,

facts.text: Regional Transport Officer notified the application for variation and called for objections.

anchor.surface_text: The Regional Transport Officer numberified this application for variation and called for objections.

facts.text: Appellant's application and objections were heard on July 15, 1955 by Regional Transport Officer, who rejected the application.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants application and the objections thereon were heard on July 15, 1955, but the Regional Transport Officer rejected the application.

facts.text: Appellant filed Revision Petition before Government of Madras under s. 64A of the Motor Vehicles Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a Revision Petition before the Government of Madras under s. 64A of the Motor Vehicles Act,

facts.text: Madras Government by order dated December 28, 1955 set aside Regional Transport Officer's order and directed grant of variation in appellant's permit.

anchor.surface_text: hereinafter called the Act, s. 64A having been introduced into that Act by the Legislature of the State of Madras. The Madras Government after having heard objections to the Revision Petition,

facts.text: Respondent Southern Roadways Private Ltd filed petition under Art. 226 on January 2, 1956 in Madras High Court for writ of certiorari to quash Madras Government order.

anchor.surface_text: by its order dated December 28, 1955, set aside the order of the Regional Transport Officer and directed the grant of the variation in the permit of the appellant as prayed for by him.

facts.text: Writ petition heard before Rajagopalan J.

anchor.surface_text: Against the, order of the Madras Government the respondent, the Southern Roadways  Private  Ltd., hereinafter called the respondent, filed a petition under Art. 226,

facts.text: Respondent raised plea before Rajagopalan J that Regional Transport Officer had no jurisdiction to grant variation, based on Division Bench decision in Writ Appeal No. 107 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: When the petition came up for hearing before Rajagopalan, J., the respondent raised a plea which was number taken in the petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution to the effect that the Regional Transport Officer had numberjurisdiction

facts.text: Rajagopalan J on September 3, 1956 set aside Madras Government order dated December 28, 1955 holding Regional Transport Officer had no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Rajagopalan, J., following the decision in Writ Appeal No. 107 of 1955 held that the Regional Transport Officer had numberjurisdiction to deal with the appellants application for variation and that it followed that the Government of Madras had equally numberjurisdiction

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Division Bench in Writ Appeal No. 110 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant appealed against the decision of Rajagopalan, J. Although in the appeal the companyrectness of the decision in Writ Appeal No. 107 of 1955 was questioned

facts.text: Division Bench affirmed Rajagopalan J's decision on July 17, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Both these companytentions were rejected and the decision of Rajagopalan, J., was affirmed. The High Court, however, granted a certificate

facts.text: Madras High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, granted a certificate that the case was a fit one for appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on April 29, 1960 by Imam J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. April 29. The Judgment of Sinha, C. J., Imam,Sarkar and Shah, JJ., was delivered by Imam, J., Subba Rao, J., delivered a separate Judgment.

facts.text: Government of Madras issued Notification No. G.O. MS. 527 on February 14, 1953 authorizing Regional Transport Officers to exercise powers under s. 48A.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Madras issued a Notification No. G. MS. 527 on February 14, 1953, wherein it was stated that prior to the decision of the Madras High Court in Writ Petition No. 806 of 1951

facts.text: Notification No. G.O. MS. 527 was in force on July 19, 1954 when appellant applied.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, to be remembered that when on July 19, 1954, the appellant applied to the Regional Transport Authority for the variation of the companyditions of his permit,

facts.text: Supreme Court held that Regional Transport Officer had jurisdiction to vary conditions of permit by virtue of Notification No. G.O. MS. 527.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the Regional Transport Officer, Tiruchirapalli, had jurisdiction to vary the companyditions of a permit by virtue of the power companyferred Y. on him by the Notification No. G.O. MS. 527 issued by the Government of Madras.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgments and remanded case to single Judge for rehearing.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the appeal must be allowed and the judgments of the single Judge and Appellate Court of the High Court must be set aside and the case remanded to the High Court for the rehearing of the writ petition

facts.text: No rules framed under s. 133A(3) of the Act by Madras Government.

anchor.surface_text: No rules, in fact, had been framed. It will be seen from what has been stated that it is the State Transport Authority and numberother which is authorised under s. 48A to vary the companyditions of a permit of a stage carriage.

facts.text: Subba Rao J delivered dissenting judgment holding Regional Transport Officer not subordinate to State Transport Commissioner under s. 44A.

holdings.text: the High Court acted rightly in allowing the respondent to urge that the Regional Transport Officer had no jurisdiction to vary the conditions of a permit despite prior submission to jurisdiction and omission from original petition, due to intervening precedent in Writ Appeal No. 107 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, although the respondent had submitted to the jurisdiction of the Regional Transport Officer and had not in his petition under Art. 226 in the High Court taken the objection that officer had no jurisdiction to vary the conditions of a permit, the High Court acted rightly in allowing

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior submission does not preclude raising jurisdictional objection after binding precedent declares lack of jurisdiction; High Court bound by own Division Bench decision.

holdings.text: s. 64A confers only revisional jurisdiction; State Government cannot pass an order directing variation of permit conditions which the subordinate authority (RTO) lacked jurisdiction to pass.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, s. 64A is a power vested in the State Government by way of revision of orders passed under Chapter IV of the Act by any authority or officer subordinate to it. This is not a power which the State Government could exercise by way of original jurisdic- tion which was vested elsewhere.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revisional power limited to reviewing legality/propriety of subordinate's order; cannot exercise original powers vested in specific authority under s.48A; words 'as it thinks fit' confined to Act's ambit.

holdings.text: Words 'any officer subordinate to him' in s.44A include officers administratively subordinate to State Transport Commissioner, absent rules under s.133A(3) defining subordination otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: The vital question for determination is, how are the words any officer subordinate to him to be construed. In con- struing these words the provisions of s. 133A will have to be kept in mind as it was contended on behalf of the respondent that these sections should be read together.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Broad textual interpretation of 'any officer subordinate'; no rules framed under s.133A(3); administrative subordination evidenced by departmental lists and structure suffices; prefers AP HC Full Bench over Madras.

holdings.text: Regional Transport Officer had jurisdiction to vary conditions of stage carriage permit by virtue of s.44A and Notification G.O. MS. 527 dated Feb 14, 1953, which was in force on application date.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the Regional Transport Officer, Tiruchirapalli, had jurisdiction to vary the conditions of a permit by virtue of the power conferred on him by the Notification No. G.O. MS. 527 issued by the Government of Madras.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification validly delegated s.48A power to RTO as subordinate officer; resolves principal issue; consequently Govt validly exercised revisional power under s.64A.

holdings.text: Regional Transport Officer, Tiruchirapalli, is subordinate to Transport Commissioner administratively, qualifying under s.44A.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no question therefore that the Regional Transport Officers are officers subordinate to the Transport Commissioner. It is perhaps for this reason that the respondent admits

holdings.reasoning_summary: Departmental lists (Madras Financial Code, Half-Yearly List) confirm administrative subordination; no conflict with rules as none framed.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, although the respondent had submitted to the jurisdiction of the Regional Transport Officer and had not in his petition under Art. 226 in the High Court taken the objection that officer had no jurisdiction to vary the conditions of a permit, the High Court acted rightly in allowing
Order of Court. In view of the majority judgment of the Court, the appeal is allowed with costs in this Court, and the case remanded to the High Court for a re-hearing by a single Judge.

In our opinion, s. 64A is a power vested in the State Government by way of revision of orders passed under Chapter IV of the Act by any authority or officer subordinate to it. This is not a power which the State Government could exercise by way of original jurisdic- tion which was vested elsewhere.
Order of Court. In view of the majority judgment of the Court, the appeal is allowed with costs in this Court, and the case remanded to the High Court for a re-hearing by a single Judge.
